By now, the evidence is clear. Covid is airborne. 

The sooner the public knows this, the sooner they can take targeted precautions to reduce transmission. https://t.co/ktfFy5mfyf

Infectious aerosols can build up in the air like smoke. One way to check for sufficient ventilation is to measure the levels of CO2 in a room. 

Portable CO2 sensors can help tremendously, and are very easy to use. 

https://t.co/pyDm17BvAq

Not sure if your air is sufficiently clean? Try some of these hacks:

https://t.co/8WKUgOXpNN https://t.co/3R2WF86SQe

Even better: build a Corsi box! 

-more flow
-less noise
-longer lifetime

See how:
https://t.co/x9pHOhcQXv https://t.co/8zROxlxPyl

Don't have money for a HEPA system? Not to worry! 

A makeshift fan-filter system often costs one fifth as much as a portable HEPA unit, and can be very effective at removing aerosols from a room.

https://t.co/jtUKtaah9X https://t.co/sp9EP9ifeZ

Everything you'd like to know about protecting yourself and others from aerosol transmission:

https://t.co/6Jth5CxBUs

Reminder: Covid is Airborne!

Open windows, open doors, use fans, utilize high-quality filters in HVAC systems, reduce occupancy, reduce interaction time, move activities outdoors, use HEPA systems, measure CO2, and mask up (fit+filter)!

@jaybny Unfortunately not:

~330,000 total covid deaths reported

~330,000,000 people in the US

-> 1 out of every 1,000 people in the US has died of COVID.

Unfortunately, this was all avoidable. Many countries are seeing zero excess deaths this year after managing to contain the virus early. 

Fortunately, it isn't too late to join them in achieving zero COVID.

When looking at all of the US, we see that ~70% of Americans live in counties with less than 1 death per 1,000 people, and ~30% above.

https://t.co/yK0Kv9J85d

The counties above are mostly composed of small towns, but the state-level picture is not much better.

Many states are averaging more than 1 death per 1,000 people. 

https://t.co/tHvc1Dcbag

Some of the hardest hit counties are in the Dakotas, which have been some of the deadliest places on earth (for COVID deaths) for several weeks now. 

Many counties in the US are seeing more than 4,000 deaths per million. https://t.co/3kWBT2naKe

Unfortunately, we don't seem to be anywhere near finished. Quite the opposite: people are dying of COVID more often now than ever. 

We're currently seeing more than 2,500 COVID deaths reported every day. https://t.co/PwR4l3S0TS
With ~330,000 reported COVID deaths in the US, that means 1 out of every 1,000 people in the US has died of COVID. https://t.co/13xLDelWU5
And it isn't just the elderly that are dying: https://t.co/DgeR4gxtXH
Importantly, that is *with* mitigation measures in place, and it all happened in only ~3/4 of the year. https://t.co/zu6MXtP36J

One might say, "That's not so easy!" 

We know that countries in Europe (for example) can impose lockdowns strong enough to get to zero relatively quickly. 

We also know that staying at ~0 is doable. Dozens of countries are doing this. 

There is no more guesswork.

@notyourmamasfem If you impose domestic travel restrictions, getting to zero becomes much, much faster.

This also allows for 'green zones' to open up as soon as they are ready. No need to wait on all of the other areas to catch up before opening up the local economy.

@notyourmamasfem Very good question! It is a bit tough to answer. Some important notes:

-the more cases you have, the longer it takes to get rid of them
-the 'stronger' the lockdown, the faster the return to zero
-a short, strong lockdown is likely to be cheaper than a long, weak lockdown

We should all make sure our air is clean. This means:

-HEPA filters
-MERV13 (or better) filters for AC systems
-High-quality masks (the ones which don't diminish medical supplies)
-Circulating and exchanging air (this needs a route in for fresh air and a route out for the rest)
It is important that organizations like the WHO and CDC acknowledge this fact, because mitigation measures are different for different modes of transmission.

There is very little doubt that COVID is 'airborne'. 

That is to say, it is likely that a significant amount of transmission comes from very small droplets (aerosols) that can linger in the air for many hours. https://t.co/tbOM4zeX4L

6/ That's when I started the First Family Safety page and have been doing news aggregation, pseudo-citizen journalism, ever since. Honestly the last few days with the rapid progression of new findings, I feel I spend more time daily on that than my actual business.

5/ While I was recovering I realized no matter what I had, I needed to do something to raise awareness for the virus that was I felt rapidly spreading in community (there was no confirmed community spread at this time, just my conjecture).

4/ The next morning the telltale signs of pneumonia began to show themselves. 

I took extreme measures putting my family in isolation in the off chance I had somehow caught Covid-19, fasted for 3 days, used a vapor inhaler and took multiple very hot baths daily.

3/ February 9th though was a watershed moment for me when I had a sudden onset infection in my lower left lung. In the morning I was perfectly fine but by that night I had fever, chills, malaise, and extreme fatigue.
2/ "I have been following the Coronavirus since news of mysterious pneumonia began surfacing in late December and began actively taking steps to prepare my family in January in case it spread here.

6/ Supposedly, the room was only for people who had traveled to Italy or China or had a confirmed COVID-19 contact. There are very few confirmed COVID-19 cases because we do not have tests. My clinic did not have any tests at all until 3/10/20 and even then was 
only given 40.

5/ The clinic dedicated a room for possible COVID19 patients around 3/10/20. I asked why all of the patients I saw with respiratory complaints were not put in the room, and was told that they couldn't put everyone w/ a cough in the room because that was half of their patients.

4/ We have no masks for providers or patients, N95 or otherwise. Some of the staff have a single mask they have been keeping for themselves, but I do not have 
access to a mask. Patients have been coughing around me for several days now and I have had no protection.

3/ We had limited tests available as of 3/10/20, but my preceptor was not testing any of the several people coming in with respiratory symptoms as of 3/12/20, including the patient with fever and worsening dry 
cough for more than a week.
2/ The attitude of the medical providers in my clinic as of 3/12/20 has been such that providers have been openly laughing at patients coming in with cough and fever who ask about COVID-19.
